content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A quick and interesting puzzle.

g_______
_oo___o_
___d____
_____j__
_______b

I think it is a very interesting problem.
In this problem, what happens if there is a line that contains no characters at all, i.e. a line that consists only of '_'?
For example, something like this :
fffrrr
3
f 0
r 2

Does this make the following output correct?
fff___
______
___rrr

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: neat puzzle, definitely suits the game. looking forward to seeing it in clashes.
great work!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved the contribution
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Exemple => Example

Now I like it way more!
>>> for history
Unnecessary complicated by key-value sorting + spaces used as spacing (which visually confusing). 

I'd at least do one of:
1) don't use spaces in the output. Probably '.' or '_' would be ok. Especially for reverse.
2) don't overcomplicate a problem with an index sorting idea. Multitask problems are bad for CoC.
>>>

BTW my solution UPDATED
`
I = input
S = I()
d = {
    int(y):x
    for x,y in[I().split()for i in'*'*int(I())]
}
for o in sorted(d.keys()):
    print(''.join(['_',x][x==d[o]]for x in S))

`

I would suggest to reword a bit. Here is my proposal.

"""
Given a [[sentence]] and <<n>> string(s) containing a character and a number separated by spac... WAIT, just talking about Thomas... he's maybe the guy you're going to hate the most for the next ten minutes...

Thomas who probably loves languages and crossword puzzles wants to output each letter line by line to know exactly how the sentence is composed.

Thomas is also very careful and he doesn't want to miss a letter... he wants you to respect the position of each letter in the sentence by replacing the other letters by white spaces.

Thomas that apparently is quite annoying and want you to waste your time, has also preferences for certain letters, so he gives you weight for each of them and he wants you to print each line respecting <<the weight in ascending order>>.

Exemple:
line 1: hello
line 2: 4
4 lines : "h 0", "e 5","l 15", "o 10"

Output:
'h____'
'_e___'
'___o'
'__ll_'

'_' represents white space.

"""

I did not like the story though and I think we can remove from annoying coders more in CoC. Phrases like "Thomas that apparently is quite annoying..." is not suited.

You should also mention somewhere that if there are duplicate letters print them in same line preserving the positions.

Can anybody explains validator 4?
03232988
5
9 30
8 20
3 40
2 10
0 0

Also isn't example output wrong? I assume the spaces needs to be considered for each character vertically from top.

Move Example from the statement to the first test case.
If you don't want to show it to the reverse players then do a separate contribution for the reverse.
The first test case is included at the end of the description and it should represent the typical average case for the problem. Not some corner case.

The statement needs full rework.
First of all, try not to over-describe an input format in the goal. People can figure out that sentence is a string and they can't it's still specified in the output description.
>...and n string(s) containing...
n lines
try something like: `For each of those lines, you need to output the original statement with all letters other than the one in the line replaced with white space`
And I don't know how to incorporate sorting in this.
I guess you need some narrative like
`
Bob works in the department of letters. Department has a budget problem and they can afford only one letter so they need to cut all others. They know letters' popularity rates but they still want to know how different sentences would look.
So, you're given a sentence and n lines. In each line, there is a letter and its popularity rate.
For each given letter you need to output how the sentence would look if all other letters were replaced with whitespaces. And you need to output it in ascending letter popularity order.
`
You can replace the popularity rate with a priority.
The idea is to tie ordering up to rate/priority so it's more intuitive. You don't need to explain jumps and it's harder to miss if it's in the format of the story and not in the rules list.

The output example in the description doesn't have the correct spacing, there should be 2 spaces before ll and 4 before o, which makes the problem hard to understand. Are multiple spaces are being collapsed into one by html formatting? Perhaps "." should be used instead of space.

The input should say that each number k is unique, otherwise a unique output character isn't well defined. But there could also be an alternative version of this puzzle where the k were not unique, and interesting ascii art could be generated.

The most annoying part of this puzzle is the "considering the order given by the number associated with each letter". It took me a long time to realise that we aren't outputting each line in correspondence with the input (which would make this a straight-forward and perfect difficulty clash), but that you are asking us to solve each line and then output them in an order specified by the integers given with each line...

I feel the ordering is an unnecessary complication that adds nothing to the challenge except frustration for people trying to solve it. I like the core puzzle, but I recommend removing the ordering part or otherwise making it MUCH more clear in the description (perhaps by changing the hello example to "o 3", "e 1", "h 0", "l 2" as input).

The statement is not very clear. Also the first example gives a very wrong perception that the indices will be consecutive. I think mentioning this was very important. Apart from that, the puzzle is good enough for a clash.

Not able to understand the problem. What do you mean by "only letter by letter replacing the others by spaces"?

Explanation of the example might be helpful. 

This problem is not fit for Reverse mode.

Cool idea. I like it when you can figure out both what is expected and how to solve the problem just by looking at the validators.

The output part of statement is unclear though (just after the initial example). It may be a format problem.

>looking at the validators
Validators are not shown to the player tho.
Do you mean "tests"?
It fits for Reverse just fine even as it is

Ruby solution
s = gets.chomp
n = gets.to_i
arr = []
n.times do
    l, i = gets.split
    arr << [ i.to_i, s.gsub(/[^#{l}]/, " ") ]
end
puts arr.sort.map(&:last)
I just change it, apparently codingame doesn't accept more than three consecutive spaces in the description...
what do you think about the new one ?

yes, it was an error in the exemple because of a coding game white spaces restriction. thank you

there is nothing special in validator 4 than the others except it is with numbers
yes you're right, thanks for your help
well I changed for underscores but I really like the sorting part...

thanks, wrong translation
if you notice any other problem with the syntax please tell me
the number is just some kind of weight, it tells the order to respect to show letters, so there is no blank line

t_____
_h____
__a___
___n__
____k_
_____s

(that one isn't a hard one :o)
Up to you. As I said I don't like too much noise. I personally don't mind a few obstacles.  With _ it looks soooo much better.

Please have a look at my last part of the above comment. Output statement does not mention about this and confusing.

Also this problem should be excluded from Reverse mode since it is hard to guess the ordering.
I just changed it ! :)
well not the reverse mode part.. I think it's not so hard to find in reverse
Why do you think it is not hard for Reverse? There is no clue that letters need to be sorted by weight.
Please explain the output. I did not get the problem.

I like it very much but it still may be confusing.
And I would say cut the first paragraph since it goes against guidelines to much.
Anyways, I already understand the goal so I can't really measure if new one is easier to read or not. But I do like it.

>unnecessary complication that adds nothing to the challenge
It adds complexity.
The reverse is kinda fun because of it.
Are you serious?

Yes.
I solved it in 5 minutes and I was very chill and relaxed. I mean, maybe I was just lucky but it doesn't seem to be very hard. And I haven't seen the statement before I've solved the puzzle. I have a script that hides it.
Can you explain the output? Author don't care to explain it seems.

You need to sort given letters by their weight in ascending order. Then for each letter, you need to output the sentence with all other letters replaced by whitespaces.
In validator 4:
the sentence: 03232988
letters:
9 30
8 20
3 40
2 10
0 0
sorted:
0 0
2 10
8 20
9 30
3 40
For "0" we output "03232988" but with everything but "0" replaced with whitespaces. So it looks like that: "0       ";
For "2" it's "  2 2   ";
etc

Ah yes absolutely.
I didn't pay attention. Now that you mention it I realize I was wondering about this difference of wording.
Good to know.
Yea, whole tests/validators thing it's not very intuitive
